column1: Narrator : Smoke raises high in the sky, and a mouth-watering smell floats in the air. It’s a tavern!
column3: Narrator : Overlooking the island is a wooden cabin. On the sign above the door is a roasted pig with an apple in its mouth. This must be a tavern.

column6: Narrator : When CAPITAINE opens the door of the tavern, nobody but dust greets him. The tavern is abandoned to webs and mold.

column1: Narrator : At this time of day, the tavern is crowded. Patrons are screaming and fighting, and laughter can be heard all around.
column2: Narrator : Despite the time of the day, nothing goes on much. The silence rules, and only a few day drinkers sip lightly at their cups.
column3: Narrator : The inn is full. A huge fireplace lights the room. Everybody’s talking about their day on sea. The air reeks of alcohol.
column4: Narrator : The inn is absolutly empty tonight… The keeper is half asleep on the counter, a few drinkers are blind drunk on the tables at the back.

column7: Narrator : The sunlight doesn’t reach further into the room. It’s pitch black and CAPITAINE can’t see anything.

column9: Choice : I don’t have any lantern…

column7: PlayerSpeak : We can see much better!
column9: PlayerSpeak : I wish I had a lantern...

column5: Narrator : A handful of musicians performing at the back of the tavern are entertaining the crowd.

column8: Narrator : A famous irish tune is playing, « The Wild Rover », CAPITAINE lays back and rests his ears from the heavy clatter of the waves.
column9: Narrator : A famous irish tune is playing, « Raglan Road », CAPITAINE lays back and rests his ears from the heavy clatter of the waves.
column10: Narrator : Everybody’s singing along the famous sailor shanty  « Blow the Man Down ». CAPITAINE sings along, forgetting his quest for just a little while.
column11: Narrator : Everybody’s singing along the famous sailor shanty  « Fiddler’s Green ». CAPITAINE sings along, forgetting his quest for just a little while.

column2: Narrator : The inn-keeper lays dead behind the counter.
column3: OtherSpeak : How dare you step back into my establishment?!

column1: OtherSpeak : What can I do for you ?
column2: OtherSpeak : Welcome to the NOMTRESOR Inn !
OtherSpeak : How may I serve you

column1: Choice : That will be all, thanks! (leave)
column3: Choice : Rooms! To rest a little until NEXTTIME (sleep)
column5: Choice : What’s new around the island?
column7: Choice : Does NOMTRESOR ring any bell?

column2: OtherSpeak : Sure thing! Here's what we have right now, let me know what you'd like!

column8: OtherSpeak : Obviously, all the drunks here talk about it!

column5: OtherSpeak : It’s the name my crazy old grand father gave to the inn…

column1: OtherSpeak : You think i'm not used to a good brawl?
column5: OtherSpeak : May he rest in peace old fool…
OtherSpeak : Who would name a tavern NOMTRESOR
OtherSpeak : Just attracts loonies of your type…
column7: Narrator : The crew wakes up to the sound of seagulls and the waves in the distance. They get up and go directly back to the main room.

column1: OtherSpeak : And next morning, all your booboos will be healed !

column2: OtherSpeak : Sorry, sailor, that’s not enough gold.

column1: OtherSpeak : Take the first room to the left after the stairs.
OtherSpeak : Let me take you to your room

column7: Narrator : The crew wakes up to the sound of seagulls and the waves in the distance. They get up and go directly back to the main room.
column8: Narrator : The crew wakes up in the middle of the night to the hoots of a few howls. Downstairs, the innkeeper is alone, cleaning the counter.

column1: Narrator : During the night, the sound of the floorboards creaking in the room wakes the crew.

column2: Choice : We’ll see in the morning… (sleep)
column4: Narrator : The crew wakes up. Their bags and purses are way lighter than before.

column1: Narrator : The innkeeper is trying to quietly go through the crew’s possessions.
column4: PlayerSpeak : Me gold! Who took me gold!

column7: Choice : It felt like sleeping on a rock...
column8: Choice : Just like when I was a wee lad!

column6: OtherSpeak : You already took one of our men, that’s enough!

column1: Narrator : A group of armed men is drinking.
column4: OtherSpeak : You shouldn’t have come back!
column9: Choice : How much for one of your men to join me? (trade)
OtherSpeak : 100 coins but our skills are well worth the gold!
column12: OtherSpeak : Yeah kiddo, ye heard me!

column11: OtherSpeak : Looks like your boat’s too small, mate.
OtherSpeak : You oughta swing by a carpenters to make room for one of my boys.
OtherSpeak : That’s cute but you don’t have the gold, mate.

column1: Narrator : At the back of the tavern, a man has displayed random items on a table.
column7: Choice : Show me what ye're peddlin'!
OtherSpeak : Didn't your mother teach you to say please?
OtherSpeak : Oh well. I have all sorts of things, really...
Choice : I say please if I want to.

column1: Narrator : Apart from a few sleeping drunks at the back of the room, the tavern is empty.

column10: Narrator : Uneased by the sound of weird footsteps in the hallway, CAPITAINE lays a hand on his weapon and approaches the door to investigate.
column12: Narrator : Uneased by the sound of weird footsteps in the hallway, CAPITAINE lays a hand on his weapon and approaches the door to investigate.

column10: Narrator : The sound of footsteps stops and CAPITAINE discerns the shadow of two immense feet. There is someone right in front of the door.
column12: Narrator : The sound of footsteps stops and CAPITAINE discerns the shadow of two immense feet. There is someone right in front of the door.

column10: Narrator :  The shadow behind the door gets closer to the floor and CAPITAINE lays back.
column12: Narrator :  The shadow behind the door gets closer to the floor and CAPITAINE lays back.

column10: Narrator : A piece of paper, old and torn, slips through the threshold.
column12: Narrator : A piece of paper, old and torn, slips through the threshold.

column10: Narrator : CAPITAINE storms out of the room to see nothing but the dim lit hallway.
column12: Narrator : CAPITAINE storms out of the room to see nothing but the dim lit hallway.

column10: Narrator : Getting together his spirits, he picks up the paper note and reads it outloud.
column12: Narrator : Getting together his spirits, he picks up the paper note and reads it outloud.

column1: Narrator : Two men are playing cards at a table.
column5: Narrator : Warmed and comforted by the fire, eased by the sound of waves at the window, CAPITAINE slowly plunge into a well needed sleep.
column7: Narrator : Warmed and comforted by the fire, eased by the sound of waves at the window, CAPITAINE slowly plunge into a well needed sleep.
column10: PlayerSpeak : What in the heck does this mean…
column12: PlayerSpeak : What in the heck does this mean…

column10: Narrator : Bedazzled by what just happened, he slips back into a tortured sleep.
column12: Narrator : Bedazzled by what just happened, he slips back into a tortured sleep.

column6: Narrator : The pantry door is ajar.
column9: Narrator : The pantry door is closed.

column1: PlayerSpeak : Nothing to do here anymore, let's bounce.
column2: PlayerSpeak : I reckon we need another good night of sleep

column9: Choice : (go back to the main room)(leave)

column13: PlayerSpeak : I don’t have any key…

column12: PlayerSpeak : The door is wide open.
